Award.AwardTitle: EBP: CS for All: Engaging Struggling Learners in Computer Science Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Students with disabilities constitute approximately 15% of the entire student population, and the majority of those students receive their instruction in general education classes alongside their peers. Despite the growing momentum to introduce computer science (CS) into K-12 instruction, however, little research has been done on meeting the needs of these learners. The goals of this project are to (1) investigate the challenges that students with learning disabilities face during CS instruction, and (2) develop interventions to address those challenges based on research-based practices from other content areas.

Areas of focus include Universal Design for Learning (UDL), balancing explicit instruction within open-ended CS activities, and encouraging student collaboration. To accomplish these goals, the project employs a mixed-methods research design within three rounds of data collection. First, it examines specific barriers and then progresses to two iterative studies of computing instruction that include strategies that support struggling learners. Data sources include teacher interviews, classroom observations, student artifact-based interviews, and analysis of video screen capture of students? computing activities for measures of persistence, collaborative problem solving, adaptive help seeking, and computational thinking (CT).

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teaching All Computational Thinking through Inclusion and Collaboration (TACTIC) investigated ways of improving learning and engagement of students with disabilities in CS educational activities. We focused on identifying barriers to learning as well as instructional practices that would address those barriers. Specifically, we focused on Universal Design for Learning (UDL), balancing explicit instruction and open inquiry, and student collaboration. A primary goal of this project was to create useful instructional resources and tools that are suitable for both researchers and practitioners involved in K-8 computer science education that includes a diverse population of students, including those with disabilities.  Our research occurred alongside our practice partners in Champaign, Illinois, New York City Public Schools, and Broward County Public Schools.  By collaborating with teachers, curriculum leaders, and administrators in our local community, our research sites can both inform our research efforts and benefit from the research findings immediately. Through this project, we developed case studies and teaching briefs, instructional tools related to UDL, co-teaching, working with paraeducators, CS project planning, and other supports. We also developed research instruments for both classroom observations and video analysis of students? computational behaviors. Finally, we disseminated our findings both in journals, conference proceedings, our website (https://ctrl.education.ufl.edu/projects/tactic/), and through social media.
